JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, APRIL I, 1963

0436-0

67TH YEAR

'Hopkins Joins Ivy League
oucher's SINA Plant Growth Precipitates

f
DecriesNudeCars Entrance To Upper Class
4
I(

The Goucher chapter of SINA
(Society for Indecency of Naked
Animals) will hold its regular
bi- weekly demonstration in
front of the Baltimore Bureau
Of Motor Vehicles to protest the
treat numbers of automobiles
Which are seen in public with
their hubcaps, tail pipes and
ether "private parts" indiscrimi!lately exposed.
Anna Heubeck, president of
the group stated that this deDarture from S.I.N.A.'s traditionId objectives was undertaken because "We are seriously concerned in making the world a
decent, moral place for decent
Moral concerned people to live
She commented further that
"Only the social poise which is
ctich a vital element of a Goucher education saved us from just
deteriorating, if you know what
I Mean. Thank God I have been

able to comport myself as a lady
through this whole ordeal."
A mass meeting will be held in
the snack bar on Thursday to
make all Goucher girls aware of
the danger facing them. Speakers will be Ed Schiller, of the
Johns Hopkins unit, who will
speak on "Immorality and the
Model A Ford—The History of
an Idea," and W. Michael Hendricks of the Young Americans
for Freedom whose topic will be,
"The Use of the Rickshaw as a
Solution to the Whole Thing."

Nathan Pusey, President of
Harvard University yesterday
announced in a statement to the
press that as the officious
spokesman of the Associated
Colleges of the Ivy he was extending a formal invitation to
Johns Hopkins to join the Ivy
League.
According to Dr. Pusey, "We
have issued this promotion in
the light of a satisfying improvement in the general appearance
and attitude of Hopkins undergraduate students." Accompany-

ing the distinction of Ivy League
membership, ten Hopkins students will be able to qualify for
memberships in the Honorable
Order of the Orderly Mind.
This announcement coincided
with the discovery in a Hopkins
Laboratory of a new species of
fast growing ivy which renders
the total engulfment of the campus within the realm of possibility.
Immediate reaction was issued
by The President of Johns Hopkins, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower
who announced while tugging at

CUDGEL Nixes Greeks;
Reign Of Sobriety Set
Undergradute social fraternities will be abolished as of the
resumption of classes after
Spring vacation, President Milton Stover Eisenhower announced Thursday afternoon.

his forelock that he was "ex-.
tremely gratified by this display
of generosity on the part of the
League's committee. Veritas vos
Liberabit. Onward and upward
with bricks and ivy. I'm sure this
development will improve the
University's corporate image immeasurably."
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, outgoing
Dean of Students issued a
statement incorporating t h e
changes necessitated by the University's change in status. Regimental striped ties and Bass
Weejuns will be required attire
for all underclassmen. The distasteful symbol of the Bluejay
will be discarded in favor of the
more appealing and newly purchased Afgan Hound, and the
Barnstormers is now officially
the Pentagon Club.
Robert L. Strider also made
public corresponding changes in
financial policy. Special Grants
will be made to outstanding
undergraduates who show prom-

chairman of the Committee on
Development,
Undergraduate

GOUCHER
EXTRA

WEEKLY

TOWSON, APRIL I, 1963

EXTRA

GOUCHER MERGER MADE;
SCHOOLS FACE REALITY
4frt editerniai
Much Ado
The forthcoming merger of Goucher and LovejOy
Tech will be a nice thing for everybody who is interested in these things. We need more interested people
around here. No one seems to be interested any more
and a gesture of such exciting interest and concern
for the general well being is wonderful. Why no one
has thought of it sooner is hard to imagine.
Of course there are several things which must
be thought about when one contemplates this big
change. We must he careful that nothing happens
that we will regret. It would he really sad if such a
good idea got confused and became instead a traumatic experience for all of us.
But we see no reason for this to happen. If everyone is careful and tries his best to live according to
a proper code of behavior everything will be alright.
Surely the improvement in the psychological climate
will be exciting. Never before have such challenges
been here for us to react to according to our wishes
and desires. These added stimuli will face us all with
the problems of living in the world sooner than we
had planned. It will face us with them now, in fact.
Another problem is co-ordination. Of course it
will he increased and more co-ordination means more
contact but some rules setting up a system will have
to be defined by someone. We suggest that this be
done immediately and in as constructive a way as
possible to avoid personality conflicts. If something
is done it will be fine and the new system will he fun.
In general everyone concerned with the new merger is to be congratulated. They have all been very
good in the whole affair and have done what they
think is best, and we think that that is best.
We hope anyone with opinions on the subject
under discussion does something about it in as fine
a manner as they see fit.

Prexies Foresee Sane Students
For Tidewater Institute of Tech.

The long awaited union of
Goucher College and ivy covered
Lovejoy Institute of Technology
became reality as Presidents
Ivorytower
and
Krauschaur
signed the official merger papers
today. The newly formed institution will be known as Tidewater
Institute of Technology to commemorate its location in the

state of Maryland.
The statement cited increased
opportunities for co-ordination
as reason for the merger. "Our
students were going crazy," the
two Presidents said. "They used
to mope around constantly.
spend inordinate amounts of
time hiding from reality in their
respective libraries and burst out

A.D. Marsha L. Turner Announces
Results of Co-ed Sports Squads

Athletic director Marsha L.
Turner has announced immediate repercussions in the department as a result of GoucherI vejoy Tech merger this week.

like caged animals at vacation
time. Obviously this is no way
to train the leaders of tomorrow."
The nation's newest educational institution will stress an
orientation in real world problems. "There will be no more of
this abstraction," stated the
Presidents' announcement. The
students will receive advanced
training in the techniques of
survival required by the modern
world.

was a marked increase in tryouts for the co-ed wrestling

'n' groan candidates,"Bonebending was never like this."

To the Editor:
I am concerned with the qu.1ity of Goucher-Hopkins relations,
and with the dignity with which
students
conduct
themselves
whenever representatives of the
two schools are togcther.
Lately, I have been extremely
perturbed at the behavior exhibited by many Goucher students when visiting the Hopkins
campus. Not being a fraternity
man, I am not qualified to comment on fraternity activities, but
I believe that all activities which
take place on a campus reflect
the status of the school. The oncampus dances to which Cloudier
students flock at Hopkins, are
marked
by
gross
behavior,
drunken rowdiness, and voluptuous display. As I feel myself to
be typical of the Hopkins man,
(and I do not approve of these
activities) I cannot but attribute
the generation of these behaviors
to the Goucher students who attend these functions.
I would therefore appreciate
an opportunity to point out to
Goucher students that. their College stands high in the estimation of the world, and this rating
rests on their behavior. Surely
the young women of Goucher
College have the strength to act
as ladies should, and not abase
the good social reputations of
both Goucher's and Hopkins'
reputations which our predeces.
sors worked hard to establish.
Alexander E. Karu

Of Motor Vehicles to protest the
treat numbers of automobiles
Which are seen in public with

Much Ado
The forthcoming merger of Goucher and LovejOy
Tech will be a nice thing for everybody who is interested in these things. We need more interested people
around here. No one seems to be interested any more
and a gesture of such exciting interest and concern
for the general well being is wonderful. Why no one
has thought of it sooner is hard to imagine.
Of course there are several things which must
be thought about when one contemplates this big
change. We must he careful that nothing happens
that we will regret. It would he really sad if such a
good idea got confused and became instead a traumatic experience for all of us.
But we see no reason for this to happen. If everyone is careful and tries his best to live according to
a proper code of behavior everything will be alright.
Surely the improvement in the psychological climate
will be exciting. Never before have such challenges
been here for us to react to according to our wishes
and desires. These added stimuli will face us all with
the problems of living in the world sooner than we
had planned. It will face us with them now, in fact.
Another problem is co-ordination. Of course it
will he increased and more co-ordination means more
contact but some rules setting up a system will have
to be defined by someone. We suggest that this be
done immediately and in as constructive a way as
possible to avoid personality conflicts. If something
is done it will be fine and the new system will he fun.
In general everyone concerned with the new merger is to be congratulated. They have all been very
good in the whole affair and have done what they
think is best, and we think that that is best.
We hope anyone with opinions on the subject
under discussion does something about it in as fine
a manner as they see fit.

To the Editor:
I am concerned with the qu.1ity of Goucher-Hopkins relations,
and with the dignity with which
students
conduct
themselves
whenever representatives of the
two schools are togcther.
Lately, I have been extremely
perturbed at the behavior exhibited by many Goucher students when visiting the Hopkins
campus. Not being a fraternity
man, I am not qualified to comment on fraternity activities, but
I believe that all activities which
take place on a campus reflect
the status of the school. The oncampus dances to which Cloudier
students flock at Hopkins, are
marked
by
gross
behavior,
drunken rowdiness, and voluptuous display. As I feel myself to

(and I do not approve of these
activities) I cannot but attribute
the generation of these behaviors
to the Goucher students who attend these functions.
I would therefore appreciate
an opportunity to point out to
Goucher students that. their College stands high in the estimation of the world, and this rating
rests on their behavior. Surely
the young women of Goucher
College have the strength to act
as ladies should, and not abase
the good social reputations of
both Goucher's and Hopkins'
reputations which our predeces.
sors worked hard to establish.
